Constructor Detail

Quantity

public Quantity()
zero-argument constructor that creates a default quantity of value 1 and no units.

Quantity

public Quantity(Quantity toCopy)
A constructor that takes a single Quantity argument, and creates a deep copy. By deep copy here we mean that the new Quantity will be a different object with its own instance variables, and that it will contain a copy of the Map object referenced by the argument Quantity.

Parameters:
toCopy - the Quantity object to be copied.

Quantity

public Quantity(double value,
                java.util.List<java.lang.String> numer,
                java.util.List<java.lang.String> denom)
         throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

This constructor takes in three parameters a double (the numeric value), a List of the units in the numerator (i.e., with positive exponents), and a Listof the units in the denominator (i.e., the units with negative exponents).

If either of the list arguments is null, this method should throw an IllegalArgumentException.

Parameters:
value - the numeric value
numer - the units in the numerator
denom - the units in the denominator
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

add

public Quantity add(Quantity quantity)
A method add that takes a single Quantity argument, adds this to it, and returns the result. This method should throw an IllegalArgumentException if its argument is null or if the two Quantity objects do not have the same units.

Parameters:

the result in a Quantity form

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object quantity)
A boolean method equals that takes any single Object, and returns true if and only if that object is a Quantity whose units are exactly the same as the calling object and whose value is the same when rounded to five places after the decimal point. E.g. the values 0.111112 and 0.111113 are considered equals while 0.111112 and 0.111118 are not.

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
quantity - the specified object to be compared with
Returns:
true if the quantities are equal, else return false

hashCode

public int hashCode()
A method hashCode() that returns an integer, such that equal Quantities always return the same integer.

Overrides:
hashCode in class java.lang.Object

normalizedUnit

public static Quantity normalizedUnit(java.lang.String unitName,
                                      java.util.Map<java.lang.String,Quantity> unitDataBase)

A static method normalizedUnit that takes a String (the name of a unit) and a Map(a units database). It should create a brand-new normalized Quantity equivalent to 1 of the given unit.

For example, if db is the database defined above, then Quantity.normalizedUnit("km",db)should return the quantity 1000 meter; Quantity.normalizedUnit("hour",db)should return the quantity 3600second; and Quantity.normalizedUnit("kph",db)would return the quantity 0.27777... meters per second.

Parameters:
unitName - name of unit to be normalized
unitsDataBase - the database to units to be searched
Returns:
the normalized quantity

normalize

public Quantity normalize(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,Quantity> unitDataBase)

A (non-static) method normalize that takes in a database in the same format as above and returns a copy of this but in normalized form (with all defined units expanded out into primitive units).

For example, normalizing the quantity 60 kph, given the above database, should produce the quantity 16.6666... meters per second.

Parameters:
unitDataBase - the specified database of units
Returns:
the calling quantity as a new normalized quantity

mini tests
